data.title: Peter Joseph McArdle (1874-1940)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for P.j. McArdle born 1874 Belpre, Washington, Ohio, United States died 1940 Pittsburgh, Allegheny, Pennsylvania, United States including research + descendants + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Son of [father unknown] and [mother unknown]

[sibling(s) unknown]

[spouse(s) unknown]

Descendants

Profile last modified 26 Aug 2022 | Created 23 Oct 2019

This page has been accessed 235 times.

Biography

P.J. McArdle was a well known city councilman in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania between 1911 and 1940. Prior to that, he was president of the labor union The Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel, and Tin Workers.

Peter Joseph "P.J." McArdle was born in Belpre, Washington County, Ohio. He was the son of Peter McArdle and Ann Gorman.[1] His obituary says that he was orphaned at the age of 5 and then was raised by an aunt in Clifton, West Virginia. At 16, he got his first job as a bar heater in a mill in Pomeroy, Ohio, where he worked for 5 years. Then, in 1895, he moved to Muncie, Delaware County, Indiana.[2]

P.J. married Margaret Flaherty on 21 Nov 1900 in Muncie.[3] They had 8 children.[2][4]

In his 20's, P.J. began to get involved in the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel, and Tin Workers, a labor union, and quickly was put into leadership positions. In 1905, he was elected president of the union, the youngest man to ever hold the position at that point.[5] His family then moved to Pittsburgh, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, where the union headquarters were located.[6] In 1911, he was elected to the Pittsburgh city council for the first time. He would serve on and off the council for the rest of his life.[2]

P.J. died on 1 Jan 1940 in Pittsburgh, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania.[1][2] He was buried in Calvary Cemetery in Pittsburgh.[7] After his death, the Mt. Washington Roadway in Pittsburgh, which he had advocated for on the city council, was renamed for him - the P.J. McArdle Roadway.[8]

Research Notes

P.J.'s parental family has not yet been completely identified. The following records may help in further research:

Likely marriage record for parents: "Virginia, U.S., Marriage Registers, 1853-1935" Ancestry.com, Ancestry Record 62154 #12599 (accessed 26 August 2022); Peter McArdle (26) marriage to Ann Gorman on 9 Jan 1862 in Alleghany County, Virginia, USA.

Article about brother Henry's death with info about other siblings: "Henry M'Ardle Was Killed," Muncie [Indiana] Evening Press, 6 May 1910, page 1; https://www.newspapers.com/clip/108339538/

Possible 1880 census record for the family: "1880 United States Federal Census" Enumeration District 172, Big Eagle, Scott County, Kentucky; Roll: 441; Page: 123C, family 167, lines 13-18, Peter Cardle (6 years old) in Peter Cardle (45) household; Ancestry Sharing Link - Ancestry Record 6742 #11083290 (accessed 26 August 2022).

Sources

↑ 1.0 1.1 Pennsylvania, Death Certificates, #10927, Peter J. McArdle, 1 Jan 1940, Pittsburgh, Allegheny, Pennsylvania, USA; "Pennsylvania, U.S., Death Certificates, 1906-1968," database with images, Ancestry.com, Ancestry Sharing Link, Ancestry Record 5164 #4049795 (accessed 26 August 2022).

↑ 2.0 2.1 2.2 2.3 "City and County Mourn Death of McArdle," The Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph, 2 Jan 1940, page 1 and 4; page 1 and page 4, accessed through Newspapers.com.

↑ "Indiana Marriages, 1811-2007," database with images, FamilySearch (https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:XXRY-ZYD : 8 December 2017), Peter J Mcardle and Margaret A Flaherty, 21 Nov 1900; citing Delaware, Indiana, United States, Marriage Registration, Indiana Commission on Public Records, Indianapolis; FHL microfilm 004476520.

↑ See 1910-1930 census records.

↑ "Peter M'Ardle Has Won The Contest," Muncie [Indiana] Evening Press, 20 May 1905, page 1; image copy, Newspapers.com (https://www.newspapers.com/clip/108339652/ : accessed 26 Aug 2022).

↑ "M'Ardle in Office Today," The Muncie [Indiana] Morning Star, 2 Oct 1905, page 1; image copy, Newspapers.com (https://www.newspapers.com/clip/108339688/ : accessed 26 Aug 2022).

↑ Find a Grave, database and images (https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/107557741/peter-joseph-mcardle: accessed 26 August 2022), memorial page for Peter Joseph “P.J.” McArdle (17 Jul 1874–1 Jan 1940), Find A Grave: Memorial #107557741, citing Calvary Cemetery, Pittsburgh, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, USA; Maintained by R. JJ Wayne N. Jane (contributor 50743123).

↑ Katie Blackley, "The Scenic P.J. McArdle Roadway, Named For A Politician Who Wanted Another Route To Pgh," 90.5 WESA, Pittsburgh's NPR News Station, https://www.wesa.fm/arts-sports-culture/2018-01-15/the-scenic-p-j-mcardle-roadway-named-for-a-politician-who-wanted-another-route-to-pgh : accessed 26 Aug 2022.

See also:

Wikidata: Item Q15997014, en:Wikipedia

P.J. McArdle and his career were featured on Season 11, Episode 6 of the genealogy television program Who Do You Think You Are? (US). This episode was centered around P.J.'s great grandson, actor Zachary Quinto. It first aired on 14 Aug 2022.
